item.title: Comment on Against an American sovereign wealth fund by Brian Villanueva
item.description:
The larger problem of a sovereign wealth fund is that it puts politicians (and in reality, that will be unelected appointees or bureaucrats) in control of a colossal source of economic power. We face this in California in the form of our CalPERS and CalSTRS retirement funds. The board are appointed by the governor, and since we're a one party state, they tend toward using their influence (and share voting power) in favor of LGBT, abortion, ESG, etc... things that bears little (or even a negative) correlation to earnings.

I wouldn't have a problem with a sovereign wealth fund (although Tyler's objections make sense) but only if it was restricted to buying a class of non-voting shares.

item.title: Comment on LLMs are Creative Reasoners by Jonathan
item.description:
How is this any evidence of reasoning? You can generate "novel" ideas with two or three lists of words and a couple of dice. Which is exactly what these LLMs are doing just on an inhuman scale. Maybe you should spend some time actually learning how these things work rather than drinking in bullshit hype from hucksters and VCs.
